references: Complexity analysis: Regarding the difficulty of solving the mentioned problems, the initial problem 𝐏1subscript𝐏1\mathbf{P}_{1}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be changed into a linear programming problem 𝐏1−2subscript𝐏12\mathbf{P}_{1-2}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Suppose there are N𝑁Nitalic_N general CAVs and one ego CAV. In that case, the time complexity for 𝐏1−2subscript𝐏12\mathbf{P}_{1-2}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is 𝒪⁢(N3.5⁢L)𝒪superscript𝑁3.5𝐿\mathcal{O}(N^{3.5}L)caligraphic_O ( italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3.5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L ), where L𝐿Litalic_L is the size of the input data, and the method used for optimization is the interior point method. With the K𝐾Kitalic_K constraint in (2), 𝐏2subscript𝐏2\mathbf{P}_{2}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT maintains a low complexity of 𝒪⁢(K)𝒪𝐾\mathcal{O}(K)caligraphic_O ( italic_K ). In practical applications, when addressing these problems sequentially in Algorithm 1, the total complexity is determined by the higher of the two. Therefore, in scenarios where the number of CAVs is large, the overall complexity of the algorithm is governed by 𝒪⁢(N3.5⁢L)𝒪superscript𝑁3.5𝐿\mathcal{O}(N^{3.5}L)caligraphic_O ( italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3.5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L ).

where j=1,2,⋯,N𝑗12⋯𝑁j=1,2,\cdots,Nitalic_j = 1 , 2 , ⋯ , italic_N. The sub-problem 𝐏1subscript𝐏1\mathbf{P}_{1}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a type of nonlinear programming (NLP), because of the nonlinear constraints (3), (12a) and (12b)222The product of the decision variables ρi⁢jsubscript𝜌𝑖𝑗\rho_{ij}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and di⁢jsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑗d_{ij}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are nonlinear.. For non-convex problems, global optimization methods like branch and bound, genetic algorithms, or simulated annealing might be more appropriate, but these methods can be more computationally intensive. Thus, we attempt to fully linearize the original problem. Let 𝐔=𝒫⊙𝐃=[ui⁢j]N×N𝐔direct-product𝒫𝐃subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑢𝑖𝑗𝑁𝑁\mathbf{U}=\mathcal{P}\odot\mathbf{D}=\left[u_{ij}\right]_{N\times N}bold_U = caligraphic_P ⊙ bold_D = [ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N × italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ⊙direct-product\odot⊙ denotes the Hadamard product and ui⁢j=ρi⁢j⁢di⁢jsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑗subscript𝜌𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗u_{ij}=\rho_{ij}d_{ij}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By doing so, we linearize the product term in the constraints, then 𝐏1subscript𝐏1\mathbf{P}_{1}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be reformulated as follows:

Since the variables si⁢jsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑗s_{ij}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are binary, 𝐏𝟐subscript𝐏2\mathbf{P_{2}}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a maximal flow problem, which can be solved by adding or removing links to obtain a higher throughput, i.e., the Ford-Fulkerson algorithm[86]. Specifically, as for the n𝑛nitalic_nth round, the associated link establishment 𝐒(n)←𝐒(n)\{si⁢j}←superscript𝐒𝑛\superscript𝐒𝑛subscript𝑠𝑖𝑗\mathbf{S}^{(n)}\leftarrow\mathbf{S}^{(n)}\backslash\{s_{ij}\}bold_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ← bold_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT \ { italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } if link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j)( italic_i , italic_j ) decreases the network throughput (Removing the link). Otherwise, we have 𝐒(n)←𝐒(n)∪{si⁢j}←superscript𝐒𝑛superscript𝐒𝑛subscript𝑠𝑖𝑗\mathbf{S}^{(n)}\leftarrow\mathbf{S}^{(n)}\cup{\{s_{ij}\}}bold_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ← bold_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∪ { italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } (Adding the link). As for 𝐏𝟐subscript𝐏2\mathbf{P_{2}}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we need to repeat adding/removing links until an optimal solution that satisfies all constraints is found, or a preset number of iterations is reached.
By combining the constraints and objective function Eq. (10), we formulate the throughput maximization problem as:

Upon completion of the learning process involving gradient descent and backpropagation, the autoencoder acquires the learned parameters. S5.T1.1.1.caption: TABLE I: The comparison of TMAC with three baseline methods under different parameters in terms of perception accuracy.
references: Table I presents the performance comparison of our proposed TMAC with three baseline methods under different power levels, bandwidths, and numbers of CAVs. The experimental results clearly demonstrate that our TMAC significantly outperforms FTS, DMDDA and No Fusion scheme in CAV recognition during the collaborative perception process. To ensure fairness in comparisons, we have set the default values of the parameters to be a power of 8 mW, a bandwidth of 200 MHz, and a total of 3 CAVs. Specifically, TMAC achieves superior AP@IoU scores, outperforming FTS by at least 9.38% and DMDDA by 18.46% in terms of the number of CAVs. The exceptional performance of our TMAC comes from the dynamic channel allocation by considering the importance of CAVs’ data, thus greatly overcoming spectrum scarcity in real-world scenarios. In contrast, FTS’s average channel resource allocation behavior results in resource deficiency for CAVs that require more resources, while allocating excess resources to CAVs that do not need as much. For DMDDA, the absence of compression implies that data transmission to the ego vehicle cannot be timely under limited spectrum bandwidth. Consequently, the Fuse Net may fuse data frames from different time instants, leading to performance degradation.
